greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Irregular table: row n >= 0 lists all k >= 0 such that the decimal representation of 2^k has n digits '0' (conjectured).
comment: A partition of the nonnegative integers (the rows being the subsets).
Although it remains an open problem to provide a proof that the rows are complete (as are all terms of A020665), we can assume it for the purpose of this sequence.
Read as a flattened sequence, a permutation of the nonnegative integers.
link: M. F. Hasler, Zeroless powers.. OEIS Wiki, March 2014
example: Column 0 is A031146: least k such that 2^k has n digits '0' in base 10.
Row lengths = number of powers of 2 with exactly n '0's = (36, 41, 31, 34, 25, 32, 37, 23, 43, 47, 33, 35, 29, 27, 27, 39, 34, 34, 28, 29, ...): not in the OEIS.
mathematica: mx = 1000; g[n_] := g[n] = DigitCount[2^n, 10, 0]; f[n_] := Select[Range@mx, g@# == n &]; Table[f@n, {n, 0, 4}] // Flatten (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jun 20 2018 *)
xref: Sequence A027870 yields the row number of a given integer.
results.author: _M. F. Hasler_, Jun 14 2018
